awd_titl_txt: Three-Dimensional Plasmonically Enhanced Nanopillar Photodetectors: An Integrative Design Approach
awd_abstract_narration:
Objective: This project is an integrated approach for design and development of plasmonically-enhanced photodetectors (PEPDs). A unique 3D plasmonic grating self-aligned to a patterned III-V nanopillar array enables enhanced efficiency along with speed appropriate for high-bandwidth transceiver integration on a Si CMOS platform.  Expected device performance includes quantum efficiencies > 70 % and modulation rates > 50 GHz.  

Intellectual merit: The innovative component is the unique three-dimensional geometry enabled by the vertical nanopillar-based format to circumvent two major limitations of planar plasmonics and nanostructures. This plasmonic grating provides significantly increased optical coupling efficiency resulting from tightly-confined photonic hot-spots compared to the conventional planar configuration.  In addition, these hot spots can be physically placed to overlap the carrier absorbing region rather than the lossy metal grating.  A holistic

Broader Impacts: This research project offers substantial opportunities for student participation at all levels including high-school, undergraduate and graduate/postdoctoral education and research experience.  The project is linked to K-12 projects such as Technology Road Show which takes nano- and clean-energy experiments developed by graduate students into local high school science classes.  A related program brings high school teachers on UCLA campus monthly to develop nano-related course work. Under represented minority students participate in these UCLA laboratories through targeted campus support of undergraduate and graduate programs.

por.por_cntn:
There is an ever increasing demand to shrink the size of the photodetector for the next generation optical sensing technologies such as infrared imaging and optical fiber communication systems. The benefit is higher sensitivity, faster detectors since the volume of the photoabsorbing material reduces both the noise and junction capacitance. However, as the active area of the photodetector approaches the optical wavelength, light is no longer efficiently absorbed resulting in low quantum efficiency. At UCLA, strategies for overcoming the tradeoff between quantum efficiency and diffraction limited light absorption was innovated based on selective area epitaxy of III-V nanopillars and a 3D plasmonic antenna for enhanced optical absorption. The growth of III-V nanopillars with diameter ranging from 80 - 200 nm was investigated along with the incorporation of dopants for realizing pn junctions. In order to implement the nanophotodiode technology for optical interconnects, the growth of III-V nanopillars on silicon waveguides was realized. The 3D plasmonic antenna utilizes surface plasmon polariton bloch waves and localized surface plasmons for resonant absorption in the short wave- and mid wave- infrared wavelengths. The benefit of a plasmonically enhanced nanopillar photodetector is the effective collection of light from a large optical area into the subwavelength photodetector junction area. This smaller junction area can lead to improved signal-to-noise (detectivity), higher speed operation and reduced material growth requirements. Single pixel nanopillar photodiodes were realized in the near infrared, short wave and extended short wave infrared spectral regions, showing enhanced light absorption as much 37x. Future work will focus on incorporating the single pixel nanopillar photodetectors into focal plane arrays for imaging applications and energy efficient optical links.
